facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 282 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 282 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 15, 1956 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 404 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 15, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 404 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 20, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. October 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: Ebenezer died intestate on November 22, 1945 during his year of account ending March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: One Ebenezer died intestate on November, 22, 1945, during his year of account which ended on March 31, 1946.

facts.text: Ebenezer left behind respondent Alfred, his son, and eight daughters.

anchor.surface_text: He left behind him the respondent, Alfred, his son, and eight daughters.

facts.text: Respondent assessed under s. 24B for assessment year 1946-47 after notice under s.22(2).

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year, 1946-47, the respondent was assessed under s. 24B 2  of the Income-tax Act, after a numberice was issued to him under s.22 2 , ibid.
The assessment was companypleted on March 26, 1951, and a numberice of demand was issued under s. 29 of the Act.

facts.text: Notice of demand issued under s. 29 after assessment.

anchor.surface_text: and a numberice of demand was issued under s. 29 of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent appealed assessment to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed against the order of assessment to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner,

facts.text: Penalty of Rs. 250/- imposed under s.46(1) during pendency of appeal for default in payment.

anchor.surface_text: but during the pendency of the appeal, a penalty of Rs. 250/- was imposed upon him under s 46 1  of the Act by the Income-tax officer, as he had defaulted in payment of tax on the due date.

facts.text: Appeal disposed of with minor modifications.

anchor.surface_text: After the appeal was disposed of with very minor modifications,

facts.text: Notice of demand issued to pay tax on or before December 15, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: a numberice of demand was again issued to him to pay the tax on or before December 15, 1951.

facts.text: Second penalty of Rs. 10,000/- imposed on March 8, 1952 for default.

anchor.surface_text: On his default, a second penalty of Rs. 10,000/- was imposed upon him on March 8, 1952.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Madras High Court challenging penalties.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Madras challenging the imposition and levy of penalty imposed upon him.

facts.text: Madras High Court quashed the two penalty orders.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held in his favour, and quashed the, two orders imposing penalty but granted a certificate of fitness to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held in his favour, and quashed the, two orders imposing penalty but granted a certificate of fitness to appeal to this Court. This appeal was then filed.

facts.text: Case governed by sub-section 2 of s.24B as Ebenezer died before end of year of account.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the matter fell to be governed by the second sub-section, because Ebenezer died before the end of his year of account.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that penalty could be imposed on respondent as assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the penalty companyld be imposed on respondent as an assessee.
under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Madras challenging the imposition and levy of penalty imposed upon him.

issues.text: Whether the legal representative of a deceased person, who is assessed in respect of the total income of the latter person, as if he were the assessee, can be ordered to pay a penalty under s. 46(1) of the India Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether the legal representative of a deceased person, who is assessed in respect of the total income of the latter person, as if he were the assessee, can be ordered to pay a penalty under s. 46 1  of the India Income-tax Act, is the short question that arises in this appeal.

issues.text: whether the fiction came to an end after the assessment, so that he remained a mere debtor thereafter to the Department

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether the fiction came to an end after the assessment, so that he remained a mere debtor thereafter to the Department. The answer to this question would determine the further application of the other sections of the Act.

issues.text: whether s.29, which makes a distinction between an assessee and other person, makes any difference

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether s.29, which makes a distinction between an assessee and other person, makes any difference. The High Court as well as the learned companynsel for the respondent  who pressed upon us the reasons of the High Court  referred to the words of s.29 where in addition to an assessee liable to pay the tax occur the words other person liable to pay such tax,

arguments.claim: Penalty could be imposed on respondent as an assessee

holdings.text: the penalty could be imposed on respondent as an assessee

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the penalty could be imposed on respondent as an assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal representative deemed assessee under s.24B(2) fiction, which fully extends to default under s.45 and penalty under s.46(1); undergoes all assessee procedures including appeal; not limited by s.29 distinction.

holdings.text: the fiction came to an end after the assessment, so that he remained a mere debtor thereafter to the Department

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether the fiction came to an end after the assessment, so that he remained a mere debtor thereafter to the Department.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming fiction in s.24B(2) treats legal representative as assessee completely for assessment and beyond, including levy, demand, default, and penalty; must be fully worked out per precedents like Teja Singh and East End Dwellings.

holdings.text: s.29, which makes a distinction between an assessee and other person, makes any difference

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether s.29, which makes a distinction between an assessee and other person, makes any difference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fictional assessee under s.24B(2) falls within 'assessee' not 'other person' in s.29; distinction does not limit application of ss.45/46 to such deemed assessee.

holdings.text: The generality of this definition is sufficient to include even a legal representative who is to pay the tax, though out of the assets of the deceased person

anchor.surface_text: The generality of this definition is sufficient to include even a legal representative who is to pay the tax, though out of the assets of the deceased person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-1953 definition of 'assessee' as 'a person by whom income-tax is payable' broadly covers legal representative liable for deceased's tax.

holdings.text: it is this fiction which has to be fully worked out, without allowing the mind to boggle

anchor.surface_text: it is this fiction which has to be fully worked out, without allowing the mind to boggle as was said in Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Teja Singh

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory deeming provision requires complete effect, treating deemed assessee as actual for all relevant purposes per established principle.

holdings.text: The words other Person cannot apply to a legal representative, if he is an assessee by fiction, and the section has to be worked out to its logical conclusion
holdings.reasoning_summary: Deemed assessee under fiction excluded from 'other person'; s.29 read harmoniously with s.24B supports penalty imposition.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Teja Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Teja Singh 1 applying the dictum of Lord Asquith in East End Dwellings Co., Ltd. v. Finsbury Borough Council 2 . If we turn to the definition of assessee, it says that an assessee means a person by whom income-tax is payable. A legal representative who by fiction, is decreed to be an assessee therefore, companyes within this definition, because he is a person by whom income-tax is payable, though out of the assets left by a deceased person.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Teja Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: the fiction has to be fully worked out, without allowing the mind to boggle

precedents.citation: East End Dwellings Co., Ltd. v. Finsbury Borough Council 2

anchor.surface_text: East End Dwellings Co., Ltd. v. Finsbury Borough Council 2 . If we turn to the definition of assessee, it says that an assessee means a person by whom income-tax is payable. A legal representative who by fiction, is decreed to be an assessee therefore, companyes within this definition, because he is a person by whom income-tax is payable, though out of the assets left by a deceased person. The assessment of the legal representative is then made under s. 23 of the Act, and he has the right to appeal under B. 30, which he would number have, if he ceased to be an assessee after the determination of the tax.

precedents.case_name: East End Dwellings Co., Ltd. v. Finsbury Borough Council
precedents.cited_proposition: dictum that when a thing is deemed to be something else it remains that thing for all purposes of the deeming provision

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: The words other Person cannot apply to a legal representative, if he is an assessee by fiction, and the section has to be worked out to its logical companyclusion. If he falls within the word assessee, as has been shown above, he does number fall within the words other person and it is number necessary to find in this case what persons are there meant to be included. In our opinion, the penalty companyld be imposed on respondent as an assessee.
